audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker stating that "Gumunting is only for ISA detainees", confirming this statement. He shares he was fortunate to only spend a short time, not being sent to Gumunting, but heard from others that Gumunting is easier than the "60 days" and describes being blindfolded, handcuffed, and transported in a blacked-out van. He recalls a rough ride, with the van driving in circles, resulting in disorientation and carsickness upon arrival at an unknown building, the van driving straight into the building, followed by the opening of the door. The ambient sound of passing traffic persists throughout the recording.

The audio clip starts with sounds suggesting a cloth being manipulated or moved.  Then, a male speaker describes being "blindfolded" and "brought into the room". He continues describing the experience, mentioning that once they are "in the room, they remove the blindfold."

The clip begins with a male speaker detailing prison conditions, describing an 8-by-9-foot square box, referring to a "pigeon hole" for food, and emphasizing the lack of windows. A second male interjects with dimensions. The first male clarifies and continues describing the food.

The audio clip begins with the sound of traffic. A male speaker then describes his living conditions for two months; the cement floor, lack of slippers, no bed, pillow, or mattress, sleeping on plywood that caused itching. He mentions a hole in the corner of the room that served as a toilet. He suggests visualizing living in a toilet for 60 days without opening the door to understand his experience.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker suggesting that "raising the community is better" and emphasizing movement and mixing. He contrasts this with being "under solitary confinement." In the background, there is speech alongside consistent sounds, possibly indicating a public or group setting.

The audio clip begins with two male speakers engaged in a casual conversation. One man asks about exercise, and the other replies in a dismissive tone, saying, "No, no, not really." He continues to describe being kept in a "concrete box," and that the guards don't talk to them or wear watches, so they lose track of time. The other man interjects, adding that the guards don't try to question them.

The audio begins with speech between two male speakers. One of them speaks about how many people were interrogated, saying "I had eight interrogated." He also mentions some were taken out and brought up, then walked through a lane with red lights to a room. He also speaks of a "green room" with green lights. The second male speaker asks questions. There is a background sound of the outdoors.

The clip begins with one male speaker recounting a story of interrogation, characterized by an annoyed tone. He describes being asked to recount his entire life from birth. He notes their irritation when he jokes about the weather during his birth. Light background sounds of a car can be heard through the duration of his storytelling.

The clip features one male speaker recounting a past conversation. He recalls his advantage in using English and how he challenged others to speak Malay first before reverting to English. The narrative is interspersed with direct quotes where he mimics different speaking tones to differentiate between himself and others. The background sounds suggest an outdoor environment, possibly near a road, due to the presence of traffic.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing a "debate" scenario, specifying that the second 60 days were particularly debate-focused compared to the first 60 days which were more Q&A-style. He mentions questions, replies, and a stick document of about 200 pages, as well as exams of 300 pages, culminating in a "statement" that he had to sign, a confession of a crime, and he talks about it being documented. The tone transitions from informational to declarative. Background noise and a slight echo give the impression of an indoor recording, with possible external ambient noise hinting at an outdoor environment.

The clip features a conversation with a man explaining that no one is charged with a crime, but, according to those in charge, everyone has committed crimes, especially if they feel you are "dangerous, non-reformed" or haven't "repented". Despite this, the speaker points out that nobody in community has been formally charged. The tone is conversational but serious, and he emphasizes the discrepancy between being accused and being charged. The speaker expresses the language used implies a committed crime.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker asking if the accusers stated the nature of the crime, and another male responds, saying the crime is "acting prejudicial to the security of this country." He states that they also believe he is a threat to national security. He then repeats what they have accused him of, "So I acted prejudicial to the security, and they believe I am a threat to national security. That's my crime."

The audio clip begins with a male speaker, seemingly in a conversational tone, asking, "Specifically what I've done?". He then continues, explaining that he will spend 60 days going through a list, and he will show what has been done. He says, "in short, they don't know what I've done", then stating they are trying to fish to see what they can find. He asks "specifically what is it I've done?". He then states that "we have plenty of time, we have 60 days with you". Finally, he is heard explaining that they will go slowly with him to show him what he has done. This is immediately followed by a brief, sharp sound, like a click.

The audio begins with speech from a single male speaker discussing a crime and related legal terminology. He mentions words like "threat to the security" and phrases such as "detention order," and "internal security act," along with, "we believe, you are a threat to national security," adopting a conversational tone. He contrasts "we believe" with "reason to believe". A distinct sound of speech, "hm," interrupts the first speaker, seemingly indicating agreement or acknowledgement. The first speaker continues using a similarly conversational tone.
